Building a Dashboard

Build a data-rich dashboard application with charts, real-time updates, and data fetching in PhilJS.

What We'll Build

In this tutorial, we'll create a comprehensive analytics dashboard that demonstrates:

  • Data fetching with async operations
  • Real-time updates using signals
  • Chart visualization with third-party libraries
  • Resource management for efficient data loading
  • Error handling and loading states
  • Component composition for complex UIs

Project Setup

Terminal
$npm create philjs@latest analytics-dashboard
$cd analytics-dashboard
$npm install chart.js date-fns
$npm run dev

Data Types

First, let's define our data structures. Create src/types.ts:

src/types.tstypescript
1export interface MetricData {
2  label: string;
3  value: number;
4  change: number;
5  trend: 'up' | 'down' | 'stable';
6}
7 
8export interface ChartDataPoint {
9  date: string;
10  value: number;
11}
12 
13export interface DashboardData {
14  metrics: MetricData[];
15  userActivity: ChartDataPoint[];
16  revenue: ChartDataPoint[];
17  topProducts: Array<{
18    name: string;
19    sales: number;
20    revenue: number;
21  }>;
22}
23 
24export interface ApiResponse<T> {
25  data: T;
26  timestamp: number;
27}

API Service

Create a service to fetch dashboard data. In a real app, this would call your backend API:

src/services/api.tstypescript
1import type { DashboardData, ApiResponse } from './types';
2 
3// Simulated API delay
4const delay = (ms: number) => new Promise(resolve => setTimeout(resolve, ms));
5 
6// Mock data generator
7function generateMockData(): DashboardData {
8  const now = Date.now();
9  const dayMs = 24 * 60 * 60 * 1000;
10 
11  return {
12    metrics: [
13      { label: 'Total Users', value: 12543, change: 12.5, trend: 'up' },
14      { label: 'Revenue', value: 45678, change: -3.2, trend: 'down' },
15      { label: 'Active Sessions', value: 892, change: 5.7, trend: 'up' },
16      { label: 'Conversion Rate', value: 3.24, change: 0.1, trend: 'stable' },
17    ],
18    userActivity: Array.from({ length: 30 }, (_, i) => ({
19      date: new Date(now - (29 - i) * dayMs).toISOString().split('T')[0],
20      value: Math.floor(Math.random() * 1000) + 500,
21    })),
22    revenue: Array.from({ length: 30 }, (_, i) => ({
23      date: new Date(now - (29 - i) * dayMs).toISOString().split('T')[0],
24      value: Math.floor(Math.random() * 5000) + 2000,
25    })),
26    topProducts: [
27      { name: 'Premium Plan', sales: 1234, revenue: 98720 },
28      { name: 'Starter Plan', sales: 3456, revenue: 69120 },
29      { name: 'Enterprise Plan', sales: 234, revenue: 56160 },
30      { name: 'Add-ons', sales: 892, revenue: 17840 },
31    ],
32  };
33}
34 
35export async function fetchDashboardData(): Promise<ApiResponse<DashboardData>> {
36  await delay(800); // Simulate network delay
37 
38  // Simulate occasional errors
39  if (Math.random() < 0.1) {
40    throw new Error('Failed to fetch dashboard data');
41  }
42 
43  return {
44    data: generateMockData(),
45    timestamp: Date.now(),
46  };
47}
48 
49export async function fetchMetrics() {
50  await delay(400);
51  return generateMockData().metrics;
52}

Metric Card Component

Let's create a reusable component to display metric cards:

src/components/MetricCard.tsxtypescript
1import { Show } from 'philjs-core';
2import type { MetricData } from './types';
3 
4interface MetricCardProps {
5  metric: MetricData;
6}
7 
8export function MetricCard(props: MetricCardProps) {
9  const trendColor = () => {
10    switch (props.metric.trend) {
11      case 'up':
12        return 'text-green-600';
13      case 'down':
14        return 'text-red-600';
15      default:
16        return 'text-gray-600';
17    }
18  };
19 
20  const trendIcon = () => {
21    switch (props.metric.trend) {
22      case 'up':
23        return '↑';
24      case 'down':
25        return '↓';
26      default:
27        return '→';
28    }
29  };
30 
31  return (
32    <div className="metric-card">
33      <div className="metric-label">{props.metric.label}</div>
34      <div className="metric-value">
35        {props.metric.label.includes('Rate')
36          ? `${props.metric.value}%`
37          : props.metric.value.toLocaleString()}
38      </div>
39      <div className={`metric-change ${trendColor()}`}>
40        <span className="trend-icon">{trendIcon()}</span>
41        <span>{Math.abs(props.metric.change)}%</span>
42      </div>
43    </div>
44  );
45}

Chart Component

Create a chart component using Chart.js:

src/components/LineChart.tsxtypescript
1import { onMount, onCleanup } from 'philjs-core';
2import { Chart, registerables } from 'chart.js';
3import type { ChartDataPoint } from '../types';
4 
5Chart.register(...registerables);
6 
7interface LineChartProps {
8  data: ChartDataPoint[];
9  label: string;
10  color?: string;
11}
12 
13export function LineChart(props: LineChartProps) {
14  let canvasRef: HTMLCanvasElement | undefined;
15  let chart: Chart | undefined;
16 
17  onMount(() => {
18    if (!canvasRef) return;
19 
20    const ctx = canvasRef.getContext('2d');
21    if (!ctx) return;
22 
23    chart = new Chart(ctx, {
24      type: 'line',
25      data: {
26        labels: props.data.map(d => d.date),
27        datasets: [
28          {
29            label: props.label,
30            data: props.data.map(d => d.value),
31            borderColor: props.color || 'rgb(75, 192, 192)',
32            backgroundColor: `${props.color || 'rgb(75, 192, 192)'}33`,
33            tension: 0.4,
34            fill: true,
35          },
36        ],
37      },
38      options: {
39        responsive: true,
40        maintainAspectRatio: false,
41        plugins: {
42          legend: {
43            display: false,
44          },
45        },
46        scales: {
47          y: {
48            beginAtZero: true,
49          },
50        },
51      },
52    });
53  });
54 
55  onCleanup(() => {
56    if (chart) {
57      chart.destroy();
58    }
59  });
60 
61  return (
62    <div className="chart-container">
63      <h3 className="chart-title">{props.label}</h3>
64      <div className="chart-wrapper">
65        <canvas ref={canvasRef} />
66      </div>
67    </div>
68  );
69}

Using Resources for Data Fetching

PhilJS provides the createResource primitive for handling async data:

src/App.tsxtypescript
1import { createResource, Show, For } from 'philjs-core';
2import { fetchDashboardData } from './services/api';
3import { MetricCard } from './components/MetricCard';
4import { LineChart } from './components/LineChart';
5import './App.css';
6 
7function App() {
8  const [data, { refetch }] = createResource(fetchDashboardData);
9 
10  // Auto-refresh every 30 seconds
11  const refreshInterval = setInterval(() => refetch(), 30000);
12  onCleanup(() => clearInterval(refreshInterval));
13 
14  return (
15    <div className="dashboard">
16      <header className="dashboard-header">
17        <h1>Analytics Dashboard</h1>
18        <button onClick={refetch} className="refresh-btn">
19          Refresh Data
20        </button>
21      </header>
22 
23      <Show
24        when={!data.loading}
25        fallback={
26          <div className="loading-state">
27            <div className="spinner" />
28            <p>Loading dashboard data...</p>
29          </div>
30        }
31      >
32        <Show
33          when={!data.error}
34          fallback={
35            <div className="error-state">
36              <p>Failed to load dashboard data</p>
37              <button onClick={refetch}>Try Again</button>
38            </div>
39          }
40        >
41          <div className="dashboard-content">
42            {/* Metrics Grid */}
43            <section className="metrics-grid">
44              <For each={data()?.data.metrics || []}>
45                {(metric) => <MetricCard metric={metric} />}
46              </For>
47            </section>
48 
49            {/* Charts */}
50            <section className="charts-grid">
51              <LineChart
52                data={data()?.data.userActivity || []}
53                label="User Activity (30 Days)"
54                color="rgb(59, 130, 246)"
55              />
56              <LineChart
57                data={data()?.data.revenue || []}
58                label="Revenue (30 Days)"
59                color="rgb(34, 197, 94)"
60              />
61            </section>
62 
63            {/* Top Products Table */}
64            <section className="top-products">
65              <h2>Top Products</h2>
66              <table>
67                <thead>
68                  <tr>
69                    <th>Product</th>
70                    <th>Sales</th>
71                    <th>Revenue</th>
72                  </tr>
73                </thead>
74                <tbody>
75                  <For each={data()?.data.topProducts || []}>
76                    {(product) => (
77                      <tr>
78                        <td>{product.name}</td>
79                        <td>{product.sales.toLocaleString()}</td>
80                        <td>${product.revenue.toLocaleString()}</td>
81                      </tr>
82                    )}
83                  </For>
84                </tbody>
85              </table>
86            </section>
87          </div>
88        </Show>
89      </Show>
90    </div>
91  );
92}
93 
94export default App;
i

Resources

createResource handles async operations and provides loading states, error states, and automatic re-fetching. It's perfect for data fetching in PhilJS applications.

Adding Real-Time Updates

Let's enhance the dashboard with WebSocket support for real-time data:

src/hooks/useRealtimeMetrics.tstypescript
1import { createSignal, createEffect, onCleanup } from 'philjs-core';
2 
3interface RealtimeMetric {
4  type: string;
5  value: number;
6  timestamp: number;
7}
8 
9export function useRealtimeMetrics() {
10  const [metrics, setMetrics] = createSignal<RealtimeMetric[]>([]);
11  let ws: WebSocket | undefined;
12 
13  createEffect(() => {
14    // Connect to WebSocket
15    ws = new WebSocket('wss://api.example.com/metrics');
16 
17    ws.onmessage = (event) => {
18      const metric: RealtimeMetric = JSON.parse(event.data);
19      setMetrics(prev => [...prev.slice(-50), metric]); // Keep last 50
20    };
21 
22    ws.onerror = (error) => {
23      console.error('WebSocket error:', error);
24    };
25 
26    ws.onclose = () => {
27      console.log('WebSocket connection closed');
28      // Implement reconnection logic here
29    };
30  });
31 
32  onCleanup(() => {
33    if (ws) {
34      ws.close();
35    }
36  });
37 
38  return metrics;
39}
40 
41// Usage in App component:
42function App() {
43  const realtimeMetrics = useRealtimeMetrics();
44 
45  return (
46    <div>
47      <h3>Real-time Metrics</h3>
48      <For each={realtimeMetrics()}>
49        {(metric) => (
50          <div>
51            {metric.type}: {metric.value}
52          </div>
53        )}
54      </For>
55    </div>
56  );
57}

Advanced Features

Date Range Selector

src/components/DateRangeSelector.tsxtypescript
1import { createSignal } from 'philjs-core';
2 
3export function DateRangeSelector() {
4  const [range, setRange] = createSignal<'7d' | '30d' | '90d'>('30d');
5 
6  return (
7    <div className="date-range-selector">
8      <button
9        className={range() === '7d' ? 'active' : ''}
10        onClick={() => setRange('7d')}
11      >
12        Last 7 Days
13      </button>
14      <button
15        className={range() === '30d' ? 'active' : ''}
16        onClick={() => setRange('30d')}
17      >
18        Last 30 Days
19      </button>
20      <button
21        className={range() === '90d' ? 'active' : ''}
22        onClick={() => setRange('90d')}
23      >
24        Last 90 Days
25      </button>
26    </div>
27  );
28}

Export Data Functionality

1function exportToCSV(data: any[], filename: string) {
2  const headers = Object.keys(data[0]);
3  const csv = [
4    headers.join(','),
5    ...data.map(row =>
6      headers.map(header => row[header]).join(',')
7    ),
8  ].join('\n');
9 
10  const blob = new Blob([csv], { type: 'text/csv' });
11  const url = URL.createObjectURL(blob);
12  const link = document.createElement('a');
13  link.href = url;
14  link.download = filename;
15  link.click();
16  URL.revokeObjectURL(url);
17}
18 
19// Usage:
20<button onClick={() => exportToCSV(data()?.data.topProducts || [], 'products.csv')}>
21  Export to CSV
22</button>
